title: Anorexia And Metabolic Set Point
summary:
Key ideas
- Anorexia nervosa can be seen as falling into two phases, with the second phase characterized by an inability to regain weight despite rational understanding of the need to do so.
- The lipostat is a brain system that regulates body weight by measuring the level of leptin in the blood and generating urges to eat or exercise.
- Obesity occurs when the lipostat becomes leptin-resistant, causing the brain to underestimate the level of leptin and defend a higher weight set point.
- Anorexia may occur when the lipostat becomes hypersensitive to leptin, causing the brain to overestimate the level of leptin and defend a lower weight set point.
- Anorexics fidget much more than healthy controls, which may be related to an unconscious strategy used by the lipostat to maintain control over weight.

Key learnings
- There may be a link between anorexia nervosa and the lipostat's regulation of body weight through leptin.
- The lipostat may also be involved in the phenomenon of fidgeting, which could be a strategy used to maintain unconscious control over weight.
- Brain tumors can disrupt the regulation of body weight, potentially inducing symptoms similar to anorexia nervosa.

Key questions
- Is there strong evidence to support the hypothesis that anorexia nervosa is related to the operation of the lipostat?
- What factors may be responsible for the lipostat becoming hypersensitive to leptin in some people?
- Can the theory of the lipostat shed light on the causes and treatment of other eating disorders?
